reviewText:
A game based on the G1 series Transformers made by Platinum Games. So let's start out with the stuff everybody cares about. There is witch time, parry (bayonetta style), dodge offset, and all of your usual platinum combat mechanics. Each weapon has its own stats, some have special effects, others have elemental effects, and they can all be upgraded. Weapons have their own variations as well. Some have the ability to charge light attacks and one in particular can shoot out projectiles. Each character plays different and has their own special attack and ultimate attack. For example, Optimus does an AoE attack with his trailer attached as his special and his ultimate attack is a ground pound which is another AoE attack. The guns automatically lock-on, so it makes shooting easy. You can also blind fire like you would in MGR. Each character is capable of holding four weapons total and has their own attachments and stats.

The stages vary from being open-ended, to morphing rooms, and linear corridors. There's also some sections that take place in special areas, but I won't spoil those. There are also hidden missions if you backtrack or find a special area on the map like Bayonetta or MGR. Think of them as hidden verses. There are a good amount of collectibles as well that you can get by destroying decepticon logos, picking up cards, etc. The upgrade system gives you plenty of reason to explore so you can find rare weapons or just fodder weapons to synthesize. There's also this little mini-game you play with wheeljack where he creates chips that you can attach to upgrade your character. It's entirely RNG-based, so expect some disappointment before getting a godly chip.

There's 50 challenges you can play post-game which are unlocked by playing the game. I also unlocked some by playing the challenges themselves. They're what you would expect from challenges. Beat enemies/bosses and do you best. The better grade you get, the better the reward. The challenges reward you with weapons and the grades go up to SS. Don't worry, the rewards stack, so you don't have to get specific grades.

The story is bla bla bla MEGATRON! bla bla bla OPTIMUS! bla bla bla Save the world.

It felt like the majority of the game you were fighting bosses which I am totally okay with. Hearing (some) of the original VAs fight it out to rockin' music was fantastic.

It took me 4 hours to beat on my first playthrough on normal. So if you're a one and done" type of gamer with character action games

reviewText:
Reviewing this game is simple.

Want Game of the Year with a gripping story, revolutionary gameplay and hundreds of hours of content? Go buy something else.

Want the video game equivalent of the most sugar-filled but delicious bowl of kids cereal you can find? Buy Transformers Devastation. It's a bowl of Fruity Pepples with a side of a Saturday morning cartoon. And everyting about it is stupid and fun.

Don't believe folks that say it's a 4 hour game. Beating the campaign once (on medium difficulty with one character of five) is 4 hours. If you want to beat it with all the characters, on all the difficulties (the 3 base + 2 hidden harder difficulties), do all 50 challenge modes, craft the best weapons , and get highest rank in everything (SS), it's considerably longer. Probably closer to 100. It's a real grind though. But a fun one.

Basically this game is what you make it. Want a pure diversion... a simple game that is just a joy to play and is nothing if not lovingly done? Play it in short intervals. Want to play this game for many, many hours? You can do that too.

If nothing else, you'll have a game that you can sit down and play for 30 minutes if you're bored or feeling down that will make you grin ear to ear every time with how fun it is. Deep? No. Fun? You'll find few games more fun. Extremely recommended.

This is literally a game I've wanted for 30 years, but never dreamed anyone would actually make. I can't even express how happy I am with this.
Platinum could have just phoned it in and made a quick cash-in game with lackluster gameplay, but this game's combat is pretty deep and rewarding. Pulling off a dodge into a combo the finishes with a vehicle strike and then moving into the character's super move is immensely satisfying. Controls are smooth and responsive, and the game plays perfectly with a Xbox 360 controller. It also has a stat and weapon upgrade system that lets you boost the character's power as you progress (and you'll need it, I've already run into a few points where I had to stop and go back to the Ark and upgrade in order to beat a boss). I'm playing on Normal difficulty, but I'm sure I'll do another playthrough on Hard later.
Visually the game is a treat, with bright colorful graphics and perfectly on-model characters. My only complaint is that sometimes the clipping is a little odd, either on the characters themselves or with background elements clipping through the ground slightly. Also the background destruction in the cutscenes could maybe use a little more visual oomph (ie: more debris falling, particle effects, etc.) I get the impression this was a deliberate stylistic choice to emulate the look of the cartoon, though. These are mostly nitpicks, however, and the game has a definite visual polish that really does look like you're playing an episode of the 80s cartoon.
The game's sound is also impressive. First, most of the character voices are done by the actors from the original show, and although Frank Welker sounds a bit rougher now than he did back in the 80s, his Megatron is still great and Peter Cullen is of course perfect as Optimus. The only character that sounds really off is Starscream, which is understandable since the original voice actor for him, Chris Latta, sadly died a number of years ago.
The music is energetic and upbeat, written by Transformers: The Movie score composer Vince DiCola in a welcome surprise. It's not as memorable as his music for the 1986 movie, but it's still good.
The story is pretty standard, playing out much like an extra long episode of the cartoon, complete with great cheesy dialog and one-liners. It'll do.
I haven't finished the game yet, but so far it's had some decent challenge and is loads of fun. The only thing it's missing is more character variety (I'm assuming there will be some DLC characters for this later, which I will probably pick up if they're not too pricy) and a Decepticon campaign. Perhaps in the sequel...
Platinum has definitely impressed me with this game, the first from them that I've really enjoyed (sorry guys, just wasn't a fan of Bayonetta). So, do I recommend it? Heartily. If you love Transformers, if you love action games, if you just want to see some awesome cel-shaded robots beat the hell out of each other, buy this immediately.

reviewText:
PlatinumGames, Activistion and Hasbro seem to mostly have learned from last years Korra game with Transformers Devastation. Once again they've combined the best of all worlds with PlatinumGames bringing in their signature fast, combo heavy, and challenging gameplay with Activision and Hasbro bringing the 80's nostalgia of Transformers G1. This time there seems to be more fan service brought into this game this time around with familiar voice actors, refferences from G1 and even the intense rock 80's like music that will almost make you feel like a kid again.

Pros:

-5 Playable characters each with their own special abilities and weapon types each can use
-Gameplay feels like a mix of Bayonetta and Metal Gear Rising with a little Vanquish added.
-5 Difficulty levels ( 3 you start with and 2 to unlock).
-Default Difficulty is fair, but challenging. Though you may die a good few times on your first run.
-A simple but surprising gear loot system with customization on your melee and sub-weapons with different perks.
-The visuals, sound effects and music help to compliment the feel of the G1 Transformers cartoons.
-A fair amount of variety on side missions
-Fun, intense boss fights
-Minimal QTEs! A First for PlatinumGames!
-A decent variety of enemy types that range from mostly medium ground and air types to huge, bulky bosses.

Cons:

-Average playthrough will be around 4-6 hours on your first playthrough ( depending if you do the side missions )
-Combat isnt quite as varied or complex
-Cant play as the Decepticons
-Transforming between the 2 forms can be awkward at first, especially since that same button is also the dodge button.
-The game can feel like a gauntlet with constant boss fights towards the end of the game
-The story, while simple to follow, feels too familiar.
-There is some replayability with the 5 playable characters and varied difficulty levels, but not much else aside of the main game and sub-missions if you dont care much for getting the best possible score on your playthroughs.



Overall: This is an instant thumbs up from me! This is a must play for both PlatinumGames and G1 Transformers fans. However the $50 price tag is stretching it some considering the short length, the thin replayability, and somewhat limited combat mechanics. If the price tag is too much for you, there's nothing wrong on waiting for a sale. Not the best PlatinumGames title, but this is a step up from the limited budget that was put forth on The Legend of Korra. I do hope they make a sequel to this game and make it an even better, more grand title.

It's Bayonetta with robots instead of a naked lady. The gameplay feels a bit less tight/refined than those games, and there haven't been any 'setpiece' moments yet like fighting RAY in Revengeance or hell every other boss fight in Bayonetta. But it's a Platinum game at core, and the combat system is still among the best of character action games out there. Just tone down your expectations a little from the highs that Bayonetta and Revengeance brought and you should have an enjoyable time of it.

The soundtrack is also weaker than either of the other games, but the Transformers all sound like you remember them. Not that there's, uh. Much going on with that Transformers thing here. They do make some use of the fact that they can turn into vehicles and have guns but the Cybertron line is what you're looking for if you want something that expands on the Transformers universe and makes full use of it. Devastation could have easily been called Robots Punch Each Other and nothing would have been lost.

As there's not many character action games on Steam, and this is Platinum at their competent, not best, I will give it a recommendation for fans of the genre.

EDIT: I have since beaten the game since posting the review. Clocked a total of 4.5 hours on it. For a fifty dollar price you'll need to ask yourself if that is worth it. There are five Autobots that have mild-moderate playstyle differences between them and harder difficulties to replay on and higher ranks to try and achieve, so there is definitely a lot more to this game if you want to push yourself. But ifyou're a one and done gamer, then yes, it's 4.5 hours to six if you're particularly slow/bad/explorative. Setpiece moments do happen later on in the game but nothing to the scale that other Platinum titles have. I stillr ecommend it fully to fans of the developer.

reviewText:
This game should not exist.

It's an affectionate homage to a childhood favourite from a ruthless publisher best known for its factory assembly line approach to games development.

But much in the same way the original Transformers toyline was a phenomenal success thanks to Takara's toy engineering brilliance and Hasbro's marketing genius, the best parts of Transformers: Devastation can be attributed to the painstaking craftsmanship of its Japanese developer and the financial muscle of its American publisher.

The younger set, more accustomed to Michael Bay's sensitive arthouse interpretation of the franchise, might be utterly baffled by an Optimus Prime who isn't prone to viciousness and a Bumblebee not given to vindictive micturation. That's because the game pays tribute to Transformers: Generation 1 (G1) and thus draws upon on the comics, the Transformers Generations toyline, the old cartoons and most of all, the 1986 animated movie featuring those characters. So, Optimus Prime is his old G1 self (a character so noble he once insisted on being executed because he cheated at a videogame) and Bumblebee is cheery and earnest.

The game looks stunning thanks to its art direction. The cel-animated look has been done before but it's used here to evoke a very specific style from a very specific time. In a way, it's hilarious to see all that CPU power, GPU iron and software wizardry being utilised to emulate a goofy error-prone cartoon. Nevertheless the visual style works so well you might be thrashed in the game because you're too busy gawping at how cool it all looks.

There are two main gameplay modes: Story Mode and Challenge Mode. The Story Mode is divided into seven chapters with each chapter comprised of three main elements: the battles, the intermediate parts and the cutscenes.

The battles, against classic G1 Decepticons and generic fodder, are fantastic. The arenas tend to have ample room to manoeuvre around in vehicle mode and this allows for some great hit-and-run tactics when combined with the quick transformations and the rush attack move. Close-in slugfests are enjoyable as well due to the quick-fire combo system and the Focus mechanic (which slows time upon a successful dodge).

There are some minor issues. Pressing X and Y frenetically to cycle through the same efficient combos does occasionally get tiresome in the protracted boss battles against giant combiners and the reaction-sensitive gameplay might cause older, slower gamers to inadvertently kill Optimus Prime more times than the Decepticons ever did. For the most part, however, smashing Decepticons until they explode remains deeply satisfying so these battles represent Transformers: Devastation at its very best.

The intermediate gameplay portions that bridge those battles come across as filler material and these are the game at its worst. You signed up for giant robots pounding the circuits out of each other but suddenly, there are tedious platforming sections, middling overhead-view racing bits and exasperating sequences where you're dodging neon lasers or leaping through closing doorways. This could charitably be viewed as a nod to the simpler games of yesteryear in the same way the game itself is an affectionate look back at G1; a more cynical reading would be Platinum was running out of money, Activision refused to spend more and the Japanese developer was forced to scale back.

The cutscenes that bookend the Story Mode battles are uninspired. The story itself is forgettable but that never was going to be the main draw of a game inspired by an Eighties cartoon. If the dialogue minimises the cheesy humour of the old 'toons (e.g. I didn't know human teeth had skin")

reviewText:
Transformers: Devastation is an incredibly satisfying game with a stellar soundtrack and massive nostalgia for G1 Transformers fans. What's there is absolutely fantastic, the only thing weighing it down is that it feels like the budget was strained, and the end result suffered for it.

The credits are about as all-star a list as you could ever get. The Metal Gear Rising director and most of his team, the Bayonetta gameplay designer and Bayonetta 2 composer, main themes by Vince DiCola and Kenny Meriedeth, battle music by the Devil May Cry composer and his sound design company, story and script by the Transformers comics writer, and almost all of the surviving voice actors from the original series. It's absolutely clear that they put their all into this game, and it's wonderful.

The problems come in with presentation and general variety. While they got the surviving voice actors and great soundalikes, there are very few cutscenes to showcase them. Like MGR, the cutscenes use the game's assets and engine, but are prerendered videos, and it's fairly jarring against the silky-smooth 60fps gameplay. While they're all used very well, there's no denying that bosses are recycled many times. They get different attacks and vastly different setpieces, but in the end you're still fighting Starscream or Blitzwing again, which can be a killjoy for a lot of people. The lack of environments is frequently criticized, and while I think they're interesting enough to not become stale, I can definitely understand those complaints. Lastly, the collectibles feel shoehorned more than any other Platinum game, which is both good and bad since they're abundant and easy to find.

Pretty much the whole rest of the game is superb. The art design is incredibly bright and colorful, with great attention to detail in both the characters and environments. Make sure to keep an eye out for all the references to the original series scattered in the city. The story, while certainly very cheesy, is true to the source and provides great setpieces. There's not very many games with the balls to have a powerful antagonist like Devastator as the first chapter boss. The variety of weapons is already impressive by itself, but some of the legendary weapons will tickle fans' nostalgia to the bone, with appearances from fan favorite eras. The playable cast isn't large, but it covers the best variety they could have gotten, and it's worthwhile to try them all with their unique abilities and usable weapons.

The gameplay isn't revolutionary for Platinum; in fact, it's probably the most by-the-numbers combat they've done. This is by no means a bad thing in any way though, because it blends Bayonetta and Vanquish with light RPG elements to make an incredibly satisfying experience. Vehicle attacks seem silly at first, but once you try them yourself, chances are the impact of the attacks will be felt through the whole body. Hits are hard and crunchy, with every weapon type feeling perfectly tuned and a joy to wield. Guns aren't just a necessity, but also provide immense utility with the right guns and builds, and also allow for a huge amount of stylish variety when integrated into the melee combat. The variety of guns is even larger than the melee weapons, with some outlandish and truly brutal armaments available. There's nothing quite like using a gatling missile to tear through your most hated enemy types with reckless abandon.

I have few complaints about the gameplay, but they do drag it down a bit. Weapons have a solid variety of combos, but the animations aren't as stylish as you'd expect. It probably wouldn't fit for Optimus Prime to do breakdances, but for Platinum fans it could be a disappointment. Another minor complaint is that the command specials (Tetsuzanko and the 360 attack from Bayo return) don't utilize your equipped weapon, instead reverting to bare metal fists for the animations.

The campaign is 7 chapters of varying length. The game is about 5-6 hours on a first run, so players who don't care about replay value will be left disappointed. For those who want to do and find everything, though, there's easily 30+ hours here. I got over 20 hours and I've yet to even beat Magnus difficulty or half of the challenges.

Speaking of difficulty, though; BOY does this game have it. The normal difficulty is a healthy challenge when you start fresh and don't have good gear yet. The hardest default difficulty is a HUGE step up and requires incredible patience and agility to do for your first run. After completing that difficulty, another is unlocked. There are two additional difficulties unlocked by clearing the last hardest one, and both are brutal and completely unforgiving. For anyone familiar with Bayonetta's difficulty levels, the unlockable difficulties in Devastation also remix enemy placement and numbers, with some of the hardest enemies appearing at the beginning and many parts swarming you with incredibly aggressive waves of them. On these difficulties, your max HP and defense stats mean nothing--you will always die in 3 (or 2 on the highest difficulty) hits. If you can't dodge or parry flawlessly, you will not even make it past the tutorial section on Magnus difficulty. It's frustrating at first, but because the mechanics are so fluid and skill-based, it's also incredibly rewarding to succeed in. However, there are issues with the super high-end gear crafting making weapons that are really strong even for Magnus difficulty, which reminds me of how the Musou games with weapon crafting tend to have the same issue. Here it's not as glaring an issue, because your offense is largely secondary to your defense; you're absolutely required to learn enemy patterns and the openings to either dodge/parry or retaliate, because there is no room for error.

In addition to the campaign, there's 50 unique challenge missions, which range from simple defeat all Decepticon soldiers
date:
to fighting several bosses at once, to more outlandish things like playing Decepticon Darts. There's a lot to be had here as well, and some challenges also provide lucrative opportunities to acquire money and gear. Unlike a lot of games, your character progress is totally universal between modes and difficulties. Challenges will reward you with items and gear depending on your completion rank, which ends up being the best way to gear up, and within the mode you have access to all the crafting and leveling systems of your home base (dubbed the Ark, identical in function to the Gates of Hell from Bayonetta).

For hardcore character action game players, the ranking system might prove a disappointment. There are bonuses for finishing quickly and without taking damage, but far more points will come from the variety of options you used during the fight. Sometimes, this can mean purposely using weaker weapons and prolonging the fight to get the most bonuses. This is something that has annoyed some players and should be considered if you're one of them.

Now, as far as the PC port goes, it's very solid. As others are quick to point out, 60fps is the maximum framerate, and some resolution options are missing. Performance is excellent though, and I rarely have any issues at all on my outdated rig. It's definitely a game that can be played on budget builds, which was a very welcome and smart move on Platinum's part. After all, more people being able to run the game means more sales, and this is a game that requires the highest framerate to be at its best.

Without going into direct spoilers, the ending and especially the post-credits stinger are a blatant sequel hook. The story is self-contained enough that a sequel isn't necessary for that, but I do very much hope that Activision eventually greenlight a sequel and provide a higher budget.


P.S. Activision, please for the love of the Allspark, release the soundtrack for purchase. I would pay top dollar for it, and I know plenty of other people would as well.

reviewText:
Transformers: Devastation is a rare beast by all accounts: an over-the-top spectacle fighter, a game by Platinum Games, a licensed title that kicks ♥♥♥. You don’t need to be a Transformers fan to appreciate the great things in this game, so you should definitely buy it — very few people did.

Everything in this game screams of awesome: bright and colorful graphics; flashy effects; great characters; nice level design and marvelous music. By the way, many of the characters are voiced by their original actors, which reinforces the original cartoon feeling that much more.

Core gameplay is a very intense, mostly hack-n-slash, action combat with giant badass robots fighting each other. The combat itself is straightforward, but challenging and has some hidden complexity. There are different types of attacks, multiple combos, a wide variety of melee and ranged weapons, four playable characters (you can switch between them almost at any time) with different playstyle and weapons, and, of course, a bunch of different enemies which need their special approach. Also, you can transform. Which shouldn’t be a surprise to you. And transformation is useful. Which was a surprise for me. Transformation is used both in attack combos and general level navigation. The game also has a very basic weapon crafting system. Oh, well.

While keyboard and mouse controls are available and do work, I would strongly recommend to use a gamepad. At least I found it more comfortable.

It’s worth noting that the gameplay isn’t limited just to regular third-person combat — there’ll be turret sections, tunnel sections, top-down camera sections and forced scrolling sections to break up the flow of the game.

The locations are usually huge (sometimes it feels like an open-world). However, when you get in a serious fight (such as, but not limited to, boss fights), the part of the level is sealed off, creating a small arena for you.

The main story campaign is approximately 10 hours long and doesn’t outstay its welcome. The overall story is both epic, action packed and a dash silly, just like alien transforming robots are themselves. If you want more, this game can offer you a bunch of side missions, challenges, collectibles, unlockables, etc.

Overall, Transformers: Devastation is a great example of a hidden gem — everything about it is great, yet almost nobody even gave it a shot. At the time of this review SteamSpy estimates sales at ~17.5K copies. It just boggles my mind how badly this game sold. It's not like there's an abundance of this type of games on PC.

To get the nasty out of the way first, Transformers: Devastation offers incredibly cheap looking cut-scenes and a throw-away story. Even for Transformers fans, $50 is a lot to ask for. However, for Platinum Games fans, this is a title with tons of depth and dozens of hours of playtime. The five characters behave very uniquely and the amount of customization the RPG and weapon smithing systems allow really surprised me, and it helps Devastation stand out amongst Bayonetta and Metal Gear Rising. Combat is smooth and the controls are nearly air-tight, though switching between robot and vehicle modes can get a little messy sometimes in crazier situations.

Even with its G1 throwback aesthetic and straightforward story, the dialog and cut-scenes don't capture the silly magic of the 80s cartoon, nor does the game really attempt to tackle Transformers' more contemporary and sophisticated storytelling found in the IDW comics. Instead, the character interactions come off as dry and forgettable, and merely a means to connect one objective to the next. Though the returning voices are great (and the stand ins aren't half-bad either), the Transformers license isn't put to great use here for the game's presentation. The fluidness of attacks, dodges, and slick transformations however make it perhaps the best-playing TF game to date.

An absolutely must buy for fans of Platinum Games and beat em' up titles, but probably worth a bit more consideration if you're not diving it primarily for the gameplay.

reviewText:
Now, before I say anything, I openly admit a massive amount of bias towards this game. I love G1 Transformers and I love Platinum Games. This was basically a dream come true for me.

Good things: Graphically, it's great. It rocks it's own art style hella hard, and runs well even on low-spec computers. The game is a lot of fun, if a little bit repetitive, and the five playable characters offer a pretty significant difference in playstyle between them (Grimlock in particular). The game has a lot of replayability due to the aforementioned five distinct playable characters, as well as loot drops that leave you eternally hoping for the best possible drop of a weapon you want and fodder weapons to mix with it. The game starts with Easy, Normal, and Hard available, and after you beat it on Hard you unlock Very Hard, and after beating Very Hard you unlock Very Very Hard, also adding to replayability. There are some light RPG elements in leveling up your equipment (which does become a necessity at higher difficulties), but other than that it's a straightforward beat 'em up that takes most of the good elements from Bayonetta 2 (lots of variation in melee weaponry, dodging + timeslow), Vanquish (varied firearms and slick gunplay, high speed mobility), and Metal Gear Rising (the sheer scale, intensity, and insanity of some of the fights), and mashes them all together. It's a pure-blooded nostalgia trip for fans of the original cartoon, as well, featuring pretty much ever member of the original voice cast who hasn't died since 1986. The difficulty is also pretty nice, if a bit unforgiving on occasion.

Bad things: The game is not very long, so if you're not the type to replay games, it's not a great investment. My first playthrough took me about 12 hours, subsequent runs (even on Very Very Hard) take me 3-4 hours now, sometimes even less. Grinding for the best perks on gear drops for fodder weapons can get tedious if you don't get the weapon you want right away. Not every character's playstyle is going to click with you (I've put 60 hours into the game and I still can't use Grimlock well). Some fights can be very frustrating, requiring you to play nearly perfectly, especially on the unlockable difficulties.


tl;dr:
Good:
-Fun
-Great nostalgia trip, lots of references to the old show
-Good combat, both melee and ranged
-Lots of replay value
-Runs like silk even on low-spec rigs
-Story is a lot like episodes of the 1984 TV series

Bad:
-Game is short and relies on players wanting to replay it to get their money's worth
-Grinding for loot can be tedious
-Story is a lot like episodes of the 1984 TV series

reviewText:
If you're a fan of the G1 Transformers (like me), you can't go wrong with Devastation. It literally feels, sounds and looks like another episode in the series and it is also a very short one (6 or 7 hours depending on the difficulty level). In Devastation you can play as Optimus Prime, Bumblebee, Sideswipe, Wheeljack and Grimlock. Gameplay vise it's a character action game made by Platinum Games and if you've played any other games made by them, you know what you can expect here but keep in mind that this game is a Platinum's side project with a very tight budget, time and resources put in to it, so don't expect something like Bayonetta or Vanquish from it in terms of overall game quality and scale, it's more like The Legend of Korra but a much better game.

But to me and no matter how much I love the G1 Transformers, Cybertron series from High Moon Studios will always be the best Transformers games ever made just because the amount of effort, love and attention to detail put in to them. Those games were like a dream come true. As of Devastation... despite the fact that it is really short and have some cool but underdeveloped ideas, it is still really fun to play and I can safely recommend it to any fans of old school Transformers out there, just don't expect too much from it in terms of scale and enjoy it for what it is.

Final Verdict: 8/10

reviewText:
AUTOBOTS! Let's ROCK OUT!! Once upon a time, Activision approached Platinum Star and asked them nicely to make a Transformers game. As long as it was awesome, Platinum were given free reign on development (barring time and budget, of course).
So they did. And delivered.

Transformers: Devastation is a frantic beat-em-up in the same vein as hack-n-slashers Devil May Cry and Bayonetta (helps that the creator was one who helped make the previous two games and characters) as well as Metal Gear Rising. If you have played any of the three (or all of those three), the similarities with the combat system will immediately stand out.
First, the obvious. Graphics, the sounds and heck, the voices will immediately bring back nostalgiac feelings of those who have watched the Generation 1 series long ago. Even if you're not a fan of Transformers (or even of that particular series), playing this game is akin to being on a special lengthy TV episode. Heck, they even got the footstep sounds right!

The meat of the game, obviously, is how much you're going to kick ♥♥♥. Similar to high-speed action games made by Platinum, you're going in with fists, feet, swords, guns, flamehtrowers as you blow apart the no-name mooks (and have nice boss fights against the named ones) while rocking it to ROCKING music that'll get your blood flowin. True to the series, you can seamlessly transform from vehicle mode and back, with one major feature being able to ram into enemies in your vehicle mode to extend your massive combos (and you'll be doing this often). By default, you have a dodge button, which with last-minute timing will let you enter Focus mode, slowing down time while you can choose whatever way you want to counter-attack your enemies. Game will kinda want you to do this a lot, as said enemies can get numerous and WILL attack you at all possible angles.

You get five Autobots to choose from, as well as numerous weapons to equip for each (though certain ones are unable to use certain weapons). Each bot and weapon you give them (up to 4 slots, however you're limited to 3 of same weapon category, melee and guns) have mostly their own combos and moves, as well as everyone having their own unique action move as well as a super attack to use in order to pile on the damage.

Along with the above, you can also level up your characters AND synthesize weapons AND buy special moves (like parries) to make yourself into something fierce. Which, due to how the game starts, seems to want you to go in that direction. Even starting fresh on the normal (Warrior) difficulty, the robot mooks will give newbies respectable challenge and the first boss WILL make you learn how to use the Focus dodge.

There's just soo much, yet of course people are going to complain the game is short. It's both a curse and a blessing, but seeing as there are multiple achievements PLUS challenge modes you can find through the game, the product practically begs the player to replay the game half to death with ALL of the characters, so that when you feel you have mastered the combat and ranked up enough weapons to max stats, then the hardest difficulty will be the final undertaking for true bragging rights.

Wish I could say more, but my fingers are getting tired and this post is long. While in this person's view that Bayonetta and Metal Gear Rising are still the better games, Transformers: Devastation takes Platinum's well-used formula and adds on some nifty things that one hopes can make its way in any of their future titles.

TL;DR version: Hurry up and ROLL OUT, already.

reviewText:
So forget all that you know about your modern day Shia Labeouf Transformers and your Fall/War of Cybertron Transformers because these are the old original Transformers. Everything about this game is original from the voice actors to the graphics. And it works great. Admittedly I wasn’t even too huge on the transformers as a kid, when gen one was still a thing, but as soon as I heard Optimus Prime talk in Transformers: Devastation I was sent back to the early 90’s. Having the original voice actors back (for the most part) was huge but it really was only in addition to everything else that was awesome with the game. For the most part I haven’t been a fan of past Transformers games and though I thought Fall of Cybertron was good it still wasn’t great. Transformers: Devastation is far from a perfect game but I can say that overall this has been my best Transformers experience yet.

The main story line in Devastation is that Megatron and the Decepticons want to turn earth into a new version of Cybertron. Your job as the Autobots is to stop this from happening. There are of course many events that occur within that overarching plot line but I’m going to avoid those to try and prevent any spoilers. The game plays out as a hack and slash type game fighting all Decepticons that get in your way, playing as any one of the Autobots you so choose. You’ll travel from location to location completing your main quests while fighting, discovering loot and secrets hidden along the way, and playing through a series of side quests should you choose to do them. The side quests weren’t overly elaborate and mostly revolved around killing more Decepticons for whatever the current purpose might be. Throughout the game however there were quite a few nice little changes in gameplay, like a segment where you have to race a Decepticon to an objective and where the game switched over from a third person perspective to a top down camera. While the changes in gameplay weren’t the most exciting they did do a nice job at changing the game up enough to keep it feeling fresh.

So since the game is nearly completely combat does the combat handle well at least? For the most part the answer is yes. While fighting land based opponents combat was as solid as could be. The ability to quickly change between primary and secondary weapons and projectiles on the fly was nice and painless and making sure your attacks hit was never a concern. Dodging is probably the most important skill in the game which takes precise timing and it definitely took me a little bit to get dodging down well but once I got it it became a must use. If you dodge an attack at the exact right moment you’ll not only avoid taking damage, but will activate a temporary slow motion system which allows you to get some real good combos off on your enemies. The issues I had came about with flying enemies, specifically when they were packed into a group with ground based enemies. Trying to dodge the attacks from flying enemies was a bit of a challenge because the rotation of the camera just never seemed to want to function properly while there were other enemies surrounding me. In cases like this I found it was the best option to back away from combat so I could snipe the flying enemies out of the sky before proceeding. It wasn’t a huge issue but was definitely something that could have been done better. Another somewhat odd thing was that combat among regular Decepticons was very rarely a problem. I could get attacked by swarms of them and leave the battle with just a pinch of health missing but that somewhat ease was very much made up for in the boss battles, where only three or four hits will get you killed. Almost every single boss battle took me multiple attempts, and I wasn’t even playing on the hardest difficulty. Now this also wasn’t too big of a complaint. The checkpoint system saves your status very frequently so even when you die you don’t have to retread too much ground. Having to battle a boss four or five times gave me plenty of time to adjust my methods until I could kill the boss no problem.

Transformers: Devastation isn’t an overly long game either. The game consists of seven chapters which depending on how quickly you try and play through the game can take you anywhere from 6 to 8 hours. The game tends to have chapters get shorter the farther in you are. Being a game from Platinum Games, the studio behind Bayonetta and the more recent The Legend of Korra game it seems they hope players will go back and replay the game multiple times to try and uncover all of the hidden secrets and collect all the weapons but that kind of replay-ability isn’t for everyone. Speaking of weapons however, the weapon system in the game is certainly vast. There are endless weapons of each type giving you a whole lot of freedom in how you play and what weapons you use. You can upgrade and customize each Autobot to your liking, which is both great and somewhat flawed. While the ability to customize each Autobot as you like the upgrading system works on a per Autobot system, meaning that as you play through you’ll likely end up sticking to one single Autobot as opposed to switching off more frequently. It would have been a nice change to have a universal level making it easier to switch Autobots at a later level rather than the existing requirement to grind them up to point.

Transformers: Devastation is beautiful. In fact my favorite part of the game is it’s look. It truly is a great looking game which still feels incredibly authentic with the Gen one transformers. The titles biggest downfall is the actual level layout. You will constantly see assets being re-used and even bits of the level being copied and duplicated. The world just isn’t that original and luckily you have the minimap to tell you where your objective is otherwise you’d be lost trying to determine where you actually are. The world looks nice, it just could have used far more variety than it has. In its current state the world just seems kind of bland.

Overall Transformers: Devastation is a solid game. If you’re a hard core fan of Transformers, especially gen one then this one is a must buy. If your a fan of hack and slashes and don’t really care about following the story then this is also totally up your ally. That said if you’re looking for a huge game with vast and varied locations and non repetitive gameplay you’ll want to turn the other direction on this one. Platinum Games did a bang up job with the game and though it isn’t without flaws it definitely is a great service to those who’ve been waiting for some serious old school transformers action. Transformers: Devastation is especially something you’ll want to dive into if you’ve got any interest in the new Transformers Prime War Trilogy that was recently announced by Hasbro and was reported on by Mike McWhertor here.

I give Transformers: Devastation a 7.5 out of 10

PROS:
– Graphics. They’re wonderful
– Original Gen 1 voice cast is back
– Vast weapons to play how you want to play
– Fighting is, for the most part, very solid

CONS:
– Levels are very similar and reuse assets too often.
– Game is relatively short
– Boss difficulty seems to be scaled a bit too high

As somebody who's not a Transformers fan, I have to say that my thorough enjoyment of this game was more than a pleasant surprise.

The good:
-It's an engaging Bayonetta-esque 3D beat-em-up, with lots of last minute dodging, shooting, and a variety of fun melee combos.
-Transforming always feels satisfying and natural, as easy and instinctual as jumping in a platformer.
-The game does a good job of keeping things fresh by giving you a variety of mission types and little bonus challenges.
-Multiple characters and a level up system for characters and weapons gives the game a good amount of replayability.
-Pretty decent difficulty level, I died quite a few times but never enough to feel frustrated or cheated.
-The art is wonderfully cartoony and colorful, animations are fluid and satisfying, and for the most part the character design is pretty great.
-Excellent sound design
-Destructible environments are a nice touch, knocking over a tree while you're zooming towards a giant robot to punch him in the face isn't something you'll always notice, but it's a neat little detail nonetheless.

The bad:
-As cool as being a robot T-Rex sounds, Grimlock's transformation controls strangely and doesn't really feel as cool as everybody else's cars. I could probably get used to it after a while, but it doesn't feel nearly as natural as playing as Bumblebee.
-The story was pretty weak. Like I said, I'm not really a Transformers fan, but I could still pretty much tell what was going on, and it wasn't anything too interesting from my perspective. That's definitely not what I play this type of game for, though, so not a huge issue.
-It's pretty short, I finished my Bumblebee playthrough in about 7 hours. Like I said before, though, there's plenty of reasons to do a second or maybe even a third playthrough with different characters.

So in conclusion, this game was really fun, action-packed, and well presented, with only a few cons that didn't really matter to me in the bigger picture. Overall it was one of the best licensed games I've ever played. Reccomended to anybody who likes beat-em-ups, especially if it's on sale.

If you're anything like me, then the Transformers universe begins and ends with G1; everything else, especially what Michael Bay's camp has been churning out, doesn't matter.

If so, then this game... oh, boy... this game is for you.  This is the game you didn't know you've been waiting for.

There are flaws, but they're mostly forgivable.  The difficulty spikes sharply after the second boss fight, and most enemies start to seem overpowered compared to your characters' stat progression.  The action is lightning-fast and over-the-top, but starts to feel repetitive.

Many characters are glaringly absent.  For example, you won't find Ironhide, Ratchet, Prowl, or Jazz.  With many characters being recolors of each other, it seems like a missed opportunity to include Cliffjumper as an alternate to Bumblebee.  Hopefully we get the chance to see these characters resurface in DLC's or sequels.

reviewText:
Summary:
Old Transformers will be happy to know that Transformers: Devastation is exactly what you'd want out of a Licensed game. It not only does the subject justice in terms of the cartoon Transformers, but it hits the style out of the park. And in Platinum Games case, you can expect a certain quality out of them: great action gameplay with Platinum's unique style to complement the combat. The port quality is good, it performs well despite a couple lack of options. But, this has Activision's hands on the game: the game does have length problems, and the game shows signs of being rushed to market with a story line that rushes to its conclusion in the second half of the game. And the game does have some good moments of variety, but in the bigger picture, you'll feel like the game stretched out its content with the resources it had, maybe a little bit too far. In the end, I can't help but recommend it, because despite my concerns of it being rushed, it still does too many good things in the overall picture. I just can't help but wonder what it could have been.

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://youtu.be/JnRNTUHs_34

Lists:

+:
Nostalgia, Nostalgia, Nostalgia. Those fans of the original cartoons? Will love everything this game has to offer, in its cheesy lines and goofy nature.
Combat system at its core is exactly what you want it to be from a Platinum game. Going from enemy to enemy is fantastic, as the natural pacing in combat feels like a raging river: action packed, but  flowing with no resistance.
Transformed mode works into combat fantastically, and feels like a natural addition. Really surprised with this one: even though the combat is Bayonetta-lite, I was really surprised that it fit in so well into the existing combat.
The ranged fighting helps in supplementing the focus on melee fighting, especially as a combo extender.
Good weapon variety in terms of ranged weaponry that does change up fights.
I do wish there were more of them, but the chase fights work rather well with the transforming element combined with the high speed elements.
When the game changes its perspective, it helps the game feel so fresh. And yet, it still is able to work rather well. Even the turret section. And I'm saying this about a turret section. I feel dirty, but it frankly works in this case.
Music is typical Platinum: High action, but having a touch of class. Very appropriate in most every situation.
The humor is cringeworthy at times. And I love it.
-:
The game shows Activision's hand in this: this game was rushed. The typical weaving of Platinum games quality products is missing here, as things feel disconnected at times.
Not sure if the RPG elements really helped the game in the end. Felt so disconnected from everything else and not really necessary in the game.
Length of the main campaign is short. Reasonably short. And there's a lot of filler in terms of the challenges, which rehashes a lot of the scenarios from the main story mode.
You can't help but reminded of Bayonetta 2 with the fighting, and there will always be a hint of it not living up to one of the best games of 2014.
The menus, in particular with the weapons and synthesizing element, is confusing and misleading at times. It's hard to tell which equipment is equipped to who you're working with. While the information is there, it's muddy and hard to pick out from everything else there.

reviewText:
Are you a fan of the Transformers cartoon from the 80s?  If so, wait for a sale and buy this game.  The story feels like it could have come straight from two or three unused episodes from the show.  The art and music all seem appropriate (though sadly the classic theme is missing) and a lot of the old voice talent seems to have returned.  The controls are smooth and each character plays differently.

That's not to say it's perfect, though.  The game is short and environment reuse is rampant.  I know that some players are enjoying playing the game over and over again on higher difficulties and to collect better gear, but I don't see the appeal in this case.  There just isn't enough unique content.  I would have liked to have seen some transformers as unlockable characters, even if it cutting out some of the existing cast for a first run (Grimlock seems like a prime candidate for this as he has nothing to do with the plot and plays very differently from the others).  Some folks have complained that there aren't any playable Decepticons, but I felt that was appropriate given the story and the return to a classic retro style.

If you aren't a huge Transformers fan, you might want to consider picking up a different action game to enjoy.  But if you are a Transfomers fan, I don't think you'll regret buying this.  I certainly didn't!

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just for the five minute Transformers cartoon.  The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognisable.  The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there.  Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very Generation One.

But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game.  The combat mechanics are extremely well done.  Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, and woven seamlessly into combos, making it quite unlike High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games.  Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g. seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster.

There are plenty of side missions available, and some of the main game's brief forays into side-scroller, GTA1 top-down, and take-out-the-horde-with-a-turret-gun are nice changes of pace.
Simply put, short but sweet.

.Amazing frame data for player feedback and reaction

. 9/10

Whether it be the beast wars, the prime show or the war and fall of cybertron, sometimes it’s nice to go back to the roots, to find the qualities that got us hooked and paved the way for a massive franchise. Transformers Devastation is a lovingly crafted game that came straight out of an episode of the original Gen 1 cartoon, with the original designs spruced up with a colourful and shiny coat of paint and as much of the returning voice cast as humanly possible, whether you’re a transformers fan or a platinum games fan, this game is up your alley.

In robot form it’s your standard platinum game with combos and dodges ripped straight out of Bayonetta with the same quality of animation and sound design that makes every dent in a decepti-creeps face satisfying, but this game provides something unique that neither the transformers’ shows nor games have delivered, where the cars and transformations are more than just a disguise. You can finish all of your combos with a devastating vehicle attack with the potential to hit multiple enemies or even switch targets. The best aspect of this combat is how all the gameplay elements naturally feeds into each other; the finishers can leave you in vehicle form and with enough momentum to loop round and start another string of attacks, at any point you can quickly pull out your blasters and pop a few servos without stopping your combo and in some cases giving you an opportunity to launch another vehicle attack.

While the campaign may come across as surprisingly short compared to most games, it’s remedied by being compact and tightly paced with boss fights being just as common as normal enemies, for instance you will only have two fights under your belt before you have to test your metal against Devastator. These boss fights hold the best moments in the game, they’re fun, frequent and backed up by a kickass sound track which while sadly missing the touch provides a mix of rock, metal and even classical music that’s appropriate for the carnage on screen. And once you’re done fighting through the two unlockable difficulty settings (Magnus being very hard and Prime being “I hope you’re made of sterner stuff”), there’s also 50 challenge missions which offer unique bosses and enemy compositions. Ever want Grimlock to pile drive Optimus prime and Megatron AT THE SAME TIME?!!!... Mission 16.

Unfortunately between the fast and frenetic combat you will have to deal with a needlessly complex and time consuming upgrade system, throughout the game you will find heaps and heaps of loot that can be equipped or synthesised to upgrade existing weapons. I have a lot of issues with this style of progression, ultimately all the upgrades and new weapons are only raising stats that you will vaguely notice in combat, and this has the potential to throw new players into scenarios under geared, stretching a 5 minute boss fight into a 15 minute fight due to pitiful damage, and vice versa. Also seeing as how all the playable autobots can equip the same weapons (with a few limitations), there isn’t as much variety in playstyles between them besides special abilities, vehicle attacks and stats, so you will likely stick with one character throughout the game. Oh and the stats screen, you’re going to love the stats screen and the insanely slow speed that it takes to level up an autobots attributes, you can probably re-watch the 1986 movie in the time it takes to level up your second favourite character to keep up with your main. To be fair the loot does occasionally provide a novel weapon, such as Devastators’ drills or Megatrons’ fusion cannon and these weapons do add a little spice to the combat.

Another significant issue with the combat and its difficulty is that enemies can and will attack you off screen with little to no warning, the camera used in devastation is a little underwhelming with no lock-on and only designed to keep you and the current punching bag in frame and in the case of a few chase sequences it has a hard time coping with the speeds you can reach. It doesn’t so much as add challenge to the game but instead creates an air of paranoia when tackling multiple enemies, I will say that this isn’t a significant problem on a normal walkthrough but on challenge mode, where fighting multiple bosses at once with attacks that are only properly telegraphed if you’re focusing on them specifically (shockwave being a particular thorn in challenge modes because of this). The most common complaint people seem to have for this game is that it's brief. Let me explain why that works to this game's favor. At 12 hours in, I've beaten the game three times and earned roughly 20% of the achievements. The game has a rich weapon crafting system that encourages you to farm items playing on harder difficulties and beating challenges. It looks gorgeous too. If I'm bored and I have two hours, I can replay this entire game to farm some sweet loot for the next time I'm bored.

The controls are also very tight. Parries work well for me, as long as I time them well, and I don't often find myself using attacks I don't want to. As usual, Platinum has done a great job creating a combat system that is responsive and flexible. Combos end in a vehicle smash, which can break shields and cause knockbacks. I would say that my vehicle smash attacks don't always hit the targets or direction I want, but hitting that extra button is too much fun. I'm glad they put it in the game, it's like they made a mini-game for combat.

Each Autobot plays pretty differently, and weapons are (mostly) interchangable. The crafting system I mentioned earlier really offers power hunters a reason to replay, or to seek out the Challenges. You can also spend credits you acquire to upgrade your autobots and synthesize tech to buff them. If you consistently land on the gold tiles in synthesize, you'll be rewarded with some interesting and useful perks. It's worth a try cooling down between missions.

Now for the downsides:

The story is basically just sorta there, but that might have been how that cartoon was. It's been a while for me, so I don't remember if plot structure and dramatic tension were really a thing with the cartoon. Most of you will be able to guess the outcome about midway through. That said, the lore tablets offer quite a bit of insight if you care to read them.

It is brief, so people who do not enjoy re-playing a game are probably not going to like the game at its original price point. This game offers a rich experience, but you have to want it. Still, as brief as it is, they managed to re-use backgrounds and maps somehow. I know, I'm shocked too.

I heard a complaint somewhere that the game was repetitive. The structure of this game is the same as most other Platinum titles, so you'll fight some dudes, walk to a place, fight more dudes, activate a switch/solve some small puzzle, move to another place and then fight more dudes. Oh yeah, and then a boss bottle. Every level is basically this format to longer or shorter degrees. It's the combat that is supposed to sustain the game and entertain you. I'm not sure if this is a pro or con. For me, it's a pro.

And the platforming in Chapter three or four can die in a fire.

Final Verdict

If you're the type to replay a game for the purpose of mastering it, then Transformers is probably a game you'll love and should buy immediately.
If you're expecting an epic campaign, maybe try the earlier Transformer titles instead.
Those here for the nostalgia should probably wait for a price drop, especially if you have never played a Platinum game before.

The most common complaint people seem to have for this game is that it's brief. Let me explain why that works to this game's favor. At 12 hours in, I've beaten the game three times and earned roughly 20% of the achievements. The game has a rich weapon crafting system that encourages you to farm items playing on harder difficulties and beating challenges. It looks gorgeous too. If I'm bored and I have two hours, I can replay this entire game to farm some sweet loot for the next time I'm bored.

The controls are also very tight. Parries work well for me, as long as I time them well, and I don't often find myself using attacks I don't want to. As usual, Platinum has done a great job creating a combat system that is responsive and flexible. Combos end in a vehicle smash, which can break shields and cause knockbacks. I would say that my vehicle smash attacks don't always hit the targets or direction I want, but hitting that extra button is too much fun. I'm glad they put it in the game, it's like they made a mini-game for combat.

Each Autobot plays pretty differently, and weapons are (mostly) interchangable. The crafting system I mentioned earlier really offers power hunters a reason to replay, or to seek out the Challenges. You can also spend credits you acquire to upgrade your autobots and synthesize tech to buff them. If you consistently land on the gold tiles in synthesize, you'll be rewarded with some interesting and useful perks. It's worth a try cooling down between missions.

Now for the downsides:

The story is basically just sorta there, but that might have been how that cartoon was. It's been a while for me, so I don't remember if plot structure and dramatic tension were really a thing with the cartoon. Most of you will be able to guess the outcome about midway through. That said, the lore tablets offer quite a bit of insight if you care to read them.

It is brief, so people who do not enjoy re-playing a game are probably not going to like the game at its original price point. This game offers a rich experience, but you have to want it. Still, as brief as it is, they managed to re-use backgrounds and maps somehow. I know, I'm shocked too.

I heard a complaint somewhere that the game was repetitive. The structure of this game is the same as most other Platinum titles, so you'll fight some dudes, walk to a place, fight more dudes, activate a switch/solve some small puzzle, move to another place and then fight more dudes. Oh yeah, and then a boss bottle. Every level is basically this format to longer or shorter degrees. It's the combat that is supposed to sustain the game and entertain you. I'm not sure if this is a pro or con. For me, it's a pro.

And the platforming in Chapter three or four can die in a fire.

Final Verdict

If you're the type to replay a game for the purpose of mastering it, then Transformers is probably a game you'll love and should buy immediately.
If you're expecting an epic campaign, maybe try the earlier Transformer titles instead.
Those here for the nostalgia should probably wait for a price drop, especially if you have never played a Platinum game before.

Before this game was announced, I had no idea I wanted something like it. When Activision announced that Platinum was developing it, it made sense to be wary, especially after the last time they made a character-action game based on a licensed property. However, Transformers: Devastation certainly has a lot of great things going for it, which are listed below:
PROS
-Multiple playable characters (and so many weapons to boot)
-Quite a few G1 voice actors come back (It's a lot like Ducktales Remastered in that way)
-Cel-shaded artstyle (seriously, why has it taken this long to make a Transformers game like this?)
-It's actually a mix of various G1 things (The cartoon, the toys, even the IDW comics)
-Challenge mode
-Multiple difficulties and level-up system ensure replayability, along with the character variety
-Hidden secrets and easter eggs (They remenbered Kremzeek!)

With all that said, it's not perfect. There are quite a few glaring problems with the game:
CONS
-Autobots are only playable (A tad petty, but still...)
-200-weapon limit
-Story mode is WAAAAAAAY too short (I was hoping in vain that there would be a surprise last boss after the credits)
-Some of the playable character choices are a bit weird (They play fine, but I don't know what Bumblebee is doing here when he's not in the Combiner Wars toyline)

It's still a great game, one of Platinum's finest; as long as fans know what they're expecting, they should be fine. Speaking of which, the only way I can recommend it is to hardcore Transformers fans, hardcore Platinum fans, or softer-core fans of either or both when the price is dropped. Bayonetta and Revengeance are more polished, but this is good for a few hours of mindless fun, taking a trip down memory lane, or remembering that there are good things about the Transformers brand (Bayformers and Kiss Players can't bring me down when I've got something like this!).

For those looking for a quick yes or no answer, this game is definitely worth buying.
It has some flaws though that do make reading the rest of the review a good idea.

Where to start? The game begins as Optimus Prime and his Autobots rush to the city where Megatron and his Decepticons are again causing havoc. G1 anime classic setup in other words, though the character models are more based off of the current Transformers Combiner Wars/Unite line and not all original voice actors are present. The city is where you'll spend a large part of the game, even as its being cyberformed into an environment for Cybertronian life. Nothing wrong with that, but sadly enough it is somewhat bland and feels more like a model made with wooden blocks than a city where humans are supposed to dwell.  That's not to say that there are no nice spots at all, the overall is just underwhelming.

So, is combat better? Somewhat, it is very satisfying to take down bosses and the intro fights for the newest 'regular baddies' are not that bad either. But you have to face them countless times and there's VERY LITTLE variation in the regular foes. Beyond that, there's the fact that gravity is completely optional in this game. It feels like you are battling as the Balloonbots against the Blimpcons. You get more airtime than Michael Jordan on spacecake tbh.
Also, concerning boss battles, Its awesome to fight Devastator and Menasor, but you fight them too often and of the individual Stunticons you only face Motor Master. The final boss also leaves a lot to be desired. The others though are definitely awesome.

So... Did they get the characters right? Though they are a bit older, Frank Welker and Peter Cullen do their utmost best and they do spark that G1 feel that skyrocketed the franchise in the '80's. Not all is well though. Bumblebee feels more like his Transformers Animated counterpart, though the voice is a-okay. Starscream though... Okay, Chris Latta's obviously not available as he died years ago, but the current VA has no feel for the character. Starscream behaves far more like a mix of Beast Wars Waspinator and Animated Wasp in any case than the G1 character everyone loves to hate. Thundercracker and Skywarp get less lines, but they at least feel a bit more in tune. *sighs* I do hate to bring the next bit up, but why did they not ask Corey Burton to reprise Shockwave? Yeah it's just one boss battle and associated scenes, but still. The current VA sounds constipated at best.

My single biggest complaint though has to be about Grimlock. In a word, he's not the G1 badass, but the season 3 clown in terms of dialogue and the most NERFED character available. I'm serious, he has trouble munching spongecake, nevermind metal. You feel as if BUMBLEBEE is a superior combatant. And this for the leader of the Dinobots, one of the few characters in G1 who could take on Optimus Prime and Megatron as an equal in combat.

So... Buy or not buy? If you like Transformers  G1, yes you would like it enough to buy it. If you like 3d Brawlers, yes as well. If you're not over the moon for either though... Tough call, best bet is to wait for a sale in that case. This game is not perfect and it does hinge somewhat on the gamer being a TF fan.

This game would be fantastic if it was optimized for PC, but it's not. Don't get me wrong I think  it's the best Transformers video game ever made, which makes it that more painful to see how it is being handled by Platinum games and Activision.   Where are these people?  there are NO updates, NO fixes, NO customer service either from Activision or Platinum games. This game has been poorly ported and abandonned.

My biggest issue is that the resolution options are terrible, in my case it is impossible to run in 1440p.

I admit the gameplay is really fun, if you play on a Full HD or lower resolution monitor, sure go ahead and enjoy the game: the action is great, fast-paced and addictive. But if you are a PC enthusiast playing on a QHD monitor, like me, this game might feel like the most frustrating one ever as you will not be able to run it in your native resolution. I've tried everything and found no reliable method to run this title properly on my system.

My review is negative simply because I can't accept this behavior of studios releasing a title and not caring for it in the least afterwards. I would switch to a positive one if they ever released a patch that fixes the graphics settings but I'm not getting my hopes up. The studio just seems to care about consoles and Activision doesn't give a rat's ♥♥♥. 1080p on a native QHD monitor looks awful, a AAA game not supporting higher resolutions in 2016 is unacceptable.

I would rather  recommend the console version, this port is just  not as good as it deserved to be.

Frantic Arcade Fun.

I didn't have much issue with the manual camera, and was quite impressed with how the enemies don't wait for a turn. They're all in, so you can't stay still for long, and you have to watch your back. However, there are times where your character gets lost in a maelstrom of explosions and metal bodies. Also the arenas are a bit cramped and should be bigger.

The weapon upgrade system is tedious, and the tech development felt a bit pointless too. Even if your timing is good you have no control over the attributes of the tech you make, and I found myself making many that I didn't want to use.

The campaign story is weak, and traversing from one area to another is boring, but I found the arena style battles and boss battles to be really, really fun. You really have to mix up ranged weapons, melee weapons and vehicle attacks to go the distance. Due to his vehicle speed, I found Sideswipe the most fun to use.

I felt the campaign isn't worth more than one playthrough, but I was surprised how fun a lot of the challenges have been. most of them are just arenas with a few waves to fight off, but they just have this arcade-y beat-em up feel that is really fun.

The voice acting is GREAT and the graphics and art style make the perfect Generation 1 atmosphere. Even the modernized soundtrack fits really well.

If you like slow paced games or stories you won't like this game. If you like beat-em ups or Transformers, I recommend.
